awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Water filtration systems that integrate organic antibacterial membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of membranes with carbon nanoparticles to treat water for the removal of bacteria, converting it into drinking water. Well over two billion people live without adequate water sanitation, posing a major threat to human health. Diarrheal disease, which is mainly caused by poor sanitation and contaminated water, is a leading cause of death in children under five years old and vulnerable populations around the world. The common method used to ensure pathogen-free drinking water is chlorine disinfection.  Chlorine is a toxic chemical, is highly corrosive and has a negative impact on human health. One way to address water disinfection is membrane filtration. This project explores translation of novel membranes to treat water, focusing on the removal of bacteria. The proposed membranes are a modification of commercial membranes to make them more efficient, resistant and with greater durability than those available in the market.

This I-Corps project advances translation of novel membranes based on carbon nanoparticles (UDD), which can significantly reduce fecal Col/cm3 concentration in polluted water.  A death rate between 94%-97% was observed in UDD-treated water plates depending on UDD concentration. One-way Anova analyses of untreated and UDD treated samples showed a significant bacteria reduction depending on UDD concentration with a 95% confidence interval.  Moreover, when UDD was incorporated to commercially available water filtration membranes, results showed a significant difference in fecal bacteria concentration between commercial and modified membranes when T-test analysis were performed thereby enhancing its bactericidal properties. This research paves the way for the use of UDD as a new disinfection material for water treatment. The improvement of the mechanical and bacteriological properties of the membranes used for reverse osmosis potentially lowers maintenance costs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the provision of the NSF award, the FresH2O Systems project has come across significant outcomes. Membrane separation processes are increasingly advanced methods for the treatment of water and wastewater. The research findings and achievements completed during the NSF I-Corps award time enhanced the commercial and market opportunities of the fabrication of organic membrane water filtration treatment. The development of our organic/carbon nanoparticle membranes has the potential of amplifying their useful lifetime and reducing biofouling problems thereby increasing the drinking water quality and quantity.

 This technology might benefit long time-space exploration missions, as the use of these membranes to treat water is positioned as a potential, reliable and long-lasting technology ideal for producing safe water with minimum use and maintenance of the crew. Through the customer discovery process carried in the I-Corps National program, the team pivoted to a new beachhead market that enabled the innovation a broader impact and more viable target: the manufacturing pharmaceutical industry. This market was valued at USD 405.52 billion in 2020 and is expected to increase at a compound annual growth rate of 11.34% from 2021 to 2028 (Grand Review Research, 2021)

FresH2O Systems? execution, networking, and divulgation of findings resulted in the interest of future potential partners in licensing agreements. The steps taken during the time of this award have strengthened and prepared the innovation for a Technology Readiness Level (TRL) deployment stage. The researchers submitted an invention disclosure and applied for a provisional patent by the United States Patent and Trademark. Moreover, the project is looking forward to apply to SBIR phase 1 programs of various federal agencies, and a research paper will be submitted to a peer review journal.

The project was disseminated in local and academic newspapers which allowed the innovation and team?s trajectory to gain exposure. Likewise, the interdisciplinary researchers participated in innovation conferences in 2021. These events include the Water Infrastructure Conference in Phoenix, Arizona, and the Tech Connect World Innovation Conference and Expo in which the members were selected to offer a poster presentation titled: Water treatment membranes using a stable and bactericidal nanodiamond material.

 


Last Modified: 04/29/2022
Modified by: Manuel Lobato
